metadata.case_name: Manager of Biri Factory v. Respondents Nos. 2-4

facts.text: Appellant is the manager of a biri factory in Nagpur.
Respondents 2 to 4 are working in that factory.
Respondents 2 to 4 applied for leave for fifteen days from December 18, 1955, to January 1, 1956, and did not go to work during that period.
Appellant did not pay their wages for these days.

Respondents 2 to 4 applied to the Payment of Wages Authority for payment of wages which had been withheld, claiming entitlement to fifteen days leave in the year under ss. 79 and 80 of the Factories Act, 1948.
Payment of Wages Authority allowed the claim and granted Rs. 90/16/- as wages withheld for the period of leave.
Appellant filed application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before Bombay High Court, Nagpur (Misc. Petition No. 512 of 1956).
High Court held respondents 2 to 4 were workers under s. 2(1) of the Factories Act and dismissed the petition on August 6, 1957.
Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.
Respondents work at the factory and are not at liberty to work at their homes.
They work within certain hours which are the factory hours, though not bound to work for the entire period and can go away whenever they like; attendance is marked.
If any worker comes after midday, he is not supplied with tobacco and is thus not allowed to work, even though factory closes at 7 p.m.
They cannot remain later than 7 p.m.
There are standing orders: worker absent for eight days (presumably without leave) can be removed.
Payment is made on piece-rates according to amount of work done, but management has right to reject biris not up to proper standard.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondents 2 to 4 are workers within the meaning of s. 2(1) of the Factories Act, 1948.
Whether, even if workers, respondents are entitled to leave under s. 79 of the Factories Act given they can absent themselves whenever they like and remained absent longer than provided.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents 2 to 4 were not workers within the meaning of s. 2(1) of the Factories Act and could not claim benefit of s. 79.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra; Shri Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if workers under s. 2(1), s. 79 should not apply as they can absent themselves whenever they like and remained absent longer than provided in the Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Respondents 2 to 4 were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and entitled to the sum awarded.

court_reasoning.text: Test from Dharangadhara and Chintaman Rao applies: relationship of employer-employee based on right to direct what work and control manner; depends on facts of each case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts substantially different from Chintaman Rao: must work at factory, attendance marked, no work after midday, removable after 8 days absence, rejection of substandard biris indicates supervision.

court_reasoning.text: Control exercised at end by rejection; right to supervise important; piece-rate and limited freedom do not make independent contractors.
Leave under s. 79 is a matter of right after minimum working days; absence beyond does not forfeit earned leave, only wages for extra period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No record shows they did not work 240 days prior.

holdings.text: Respondents 2 to 4 are workers within s. 2(1) Factories Act.
Workers entitled to leave under s. 79 Factories Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test of employer-employee relationship: right to control manner of work.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Facts different; Sattedars were independent contractors, unlike here.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of worker; entitlement to annual leave with wages.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld confirming respondents as workers entitled to wages for leave period under Factories Act.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; respondents retain Authority award.

key_quotes.text: the prima facie test whether the relationship of master and servant or employer and employee existed was laid down as the existence of the right in the employer not merely to direct what work was to be done but also to control the manner in which it was to be done
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Considering the entire circumstances... there can be no doubt that respondents 2 to 4 are workers within the meaning of s. 2(1) of the Factories Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The leave provided under s. 79 arises as a matter of right when a worker has put in a minimum number of working days and he is entitled to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies leave entitlement independent of absences.
